> [{quoted}](name=Bahamut Zero,realm=NA,application-id=Ir7ZrJjF,discussion-id=yB0A5On1,comment-id=000d,timestamp=2017-01-22T15:35:33.437+0000)

no, i just like being expensive :^) i could, but then companies wouldn't waste all their ad money on something i'll never look at

Adblock isn't just about the annoyance of advertisements on websites.

The biggest problem with ads is the phishers/scammers/ransomware developers that push seemingly legitimate ads with very dangerous content.

Until businesses become responsible in their ad choices and deployments, it's just not safe to run without adblock unless you explicitly trust a website (e.g. reddit runs their own vetted ads, so I leave them as unblocked).

> [{quoted}](name=SnakeG,realm=NA,application-id=Ir7ZrJjF,discussion-id=yB0A5On1,comment-id=000d00000000,timestamp=2017-01-22T18:38:27.958+0000)
>
> Adblock isn't just about the annoyance of advertisements on websites.
> 
> The biggest problem with ads is the phishers/scammers/ransomware developers that push seemingly legitimate ads with very dangerous content.
> 
> Until businesses become responsible in their ad choices and deployments, it's just not safe to run without adblock unless you explicitly trust a website (e.g. reddit runs their own vetted ads, so I leave them as unblocked).

i never click any ads ever though... can they still be dangerous without ever clicking them?
No, if you don't click, you're fine.

Not true, careful when you spread false information.

Ads can serve javascript, and that javascript can expose users to viruses.

not true actually.  you should always have an up to date antivirus

I actually experienced one on a legitimate website where avast caught it before the page loaded

Yes they can, depending on how the advertisement is served.

Worst case scenario is the ad is allowed to serve up javascript.  This javascript exploits flaws in the browser and can cause a remote code execution on your computer, with your computer downloading software that you didnt expect.

While not an ad, one of the nastiest javascript exploits recently was done through compromised WordPress websites, which caused ransomware to be downloaded to unsuspecting computers via a 0-day exploit (unpatched and unknown browser hole).

The same thing has happened through ads, with software being downloaded to computers.  Often times it targets certain sections of users (such as enterprise users).  The joys of targetted ads.

So yes, scary thought.  Adblock is a safety tool, and it doesn't require you to click the ad.
do not believe the hype, there are now clickless malwares in ads
